evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim case.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the historical time period 12-25 as recorded in hist_t2_interim.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for such deficiencies in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA within the specified historical timeframe.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during the hist_t2_interim period.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim is resistant to defeaters based on available evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim is documented and accessible within the operational records and incident reports.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the procedural deviation is robust against common counterarguments or alternative explanations, supported by corroborating evidence and consistent with established operational standards for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback procedures.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation aligns with key features observed in pushback operations, including timing, communication protocols, and equipment usage specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim period.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the hist_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The tug instructor's statement reflects the overall crew communication status during the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication or warnings were given and acknowledged
If the incident was caused solely by mechanical failure or external factors unrelated to crew communication

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The tug instructor explicitly noted communication methods were insufficient and no warnings were received from other crew members before the collision (H8), indicating a documented communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Limited direct statements about communication breakdown beyond the tug instructor's perspective; no explicit documentation of communication failures from other crew members.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure occurred in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during the hist_t2_interim period.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction in the aircraft during the incident
Maintenance or technical reports indicating failure
Flight data or cockpit voice recordings showing control anomalies
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the incident; all evidence describes human actions and procedural issues related to tug operation (H1-H9).
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the historical time period 12-25 as recorded in hist_t2_interim.

defeaters: If evidence showed that the Tug Release Point (TRP) markings were missing, unclear, or otherwise deficient during the incident period.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history indicates the presence or observability of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the specified period.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of formal incident report or operational record accessibility, only history notes

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for such deficiencies in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA within the specified historical timeframe.

assumptions: The TRP marking described is consistent with the key features for environmental/marking deficiencies for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the specified timeframe.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were changed or not present during the timeframe, or if the aircraft type had different clearance requirements invalidating the marking relevance.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 describe the TRP marking and its intended clearance for the B737-800, showing the environmental marking exists and is defined. H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP, indicating a deficiency in adherence or marking effectiveness. H8 provides context on signaling deficiencies related to stopping the tug, supporting the environmental/marking deficiency aligning with key features for this aircraft and timeframe.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit documentation of the marking design standards or changes over time; reliance on incident description and instructor statements.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim scope withstands potential counterarguments and alternative causes, demonstrating strong defeater resistance.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies communication breakdown
The tug instructor's statement about visual signals reflects actual communication effectiveness
defeaters: Additional evidence of alternative causes for the collision
More direct evidence of communication failures or misunderstandings
Contradictory witness statements or procedural deviations

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows communication methods and roles were established but had limitations (H8), and the trainee driver was qualified and aware of procedures (H9). The tug instructor took over after the trainee stopped (H2) and continued communication and reassurance (H3). However, the visual signals were insufficient and no warnings were given before the collision (H8), indicating some communication breakdown. This supports that the explanation withstands some counterarguments but not all, showing moderate defeater resistance.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct evidence explicitly addressing counterarguments or alternative causes

node.statement: The procedural deviation aligns with key features observed in pushback operations, including timing, communication protocols, and equipment usage specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim period.

The described communication and equipment usage represent standard pushback operations for this aircraft and period
defeaters: If evidence showed the procedural deviation involved features not typical of pushback operations for this aircraft or period
If communication protocols or equipment usage deviated significantly from standard procedures
If timing of the deviation was inconsistent with known pushback operation timings

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim.

The visual signal method described is the standard procedure for stopping the tug

node.statement: The identification of the procedural deviation is robust against common counterarguments or alternative explanations, supported by corroborating evidence and consistent with established operational standards for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback procedures.

assumptions: The TRP and clearance standards described in H7 represent established operational standards for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback procedures.
The absence of warnings from wingman or headset operator (H8) implies a failure in communication contributing to the deviation.
defeaters: If alternative explanations for the collision were presented with equal or better evidence, such as mechanical failure or external interference.
If evidence showed that the TRP or operational standards were ambiguous or inconsistently applied.
If communication protocols or signals were proven effective and followed, contradicting the claim of procedural deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 directly document the procedural deviation (passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier) and the established operational standard (TRP location and clearance). H8 and H9 provide corroborating context about communication methods and operator qualifications, supporting robustness against counterarguments.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit documentation of all operational standards and absence of direct counterarguments in the evidence.

assumptions: Mechanical/control failure is distinct from human operational errors
Resistance to defeaters requires explicit evidence of failure robustness
defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical/control failure and its resistance to defeaters
Alternative explanations involving human error or procedural failures

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

defeaters: Direct evidence that all crew members had and used fully operational communication equipment effectively
Statements confirming no communication equipment failures or access issues

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: While communication equipment (interphone) was in use (H1), the headset operator was often out of the tug driver's field of view and visual signals were insufficient (H8), indicating that communication equipment may have been operational but not effectively available or used by all crew members.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether equipment availability equates to effective availability and use by all crew members

Evidence that markings were obscured or not visible during the incident

assumptions: Communication via interphone and headset operator implies availability of clear communication channels
Presence of qualified personnel (headset operator, wingman) implies standard communication procedures were in place
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment was malfunctioning or unavailable during pushback
If there were documented failures or absence of communication protocols in place
If the headset operator or wingman were not present or not in communication with flight crew

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H3 confirm communication channels existed between flight crew and ground crew (headset operator and wingman). H9 confirms the trainee was qualified and aware of procedures. H8 indicates that despite communication channels, no warning was given about the impending collision, suggesting communication was available but possibly ineffective or insufficient.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity about the effectiveness and clarity of communication despite availability; no direct evidence on quality or timeliness of communication
